An object capable of resolving references to existing query objects.

An SQL function call.

Represent a wrapped value as a node within an expression.

An expression that can be combined with other expressions.

An expression that can be combined with other expressions.

An expression that can be combined with other expressions.

Ref

Reference to column alias of the query. For example, Ref('sum_cost') in

An expression containing multiple expressions. Can be used to provide a

OrderByList

An SQL function call.

An expression that can wrap another expression so that it can provide

NegatedExpression

The logical negation of a conditional expression.

When

An expression that can be combined with other expressions.

Case

An SQL searched CASE expression:

Subquery

An explicit subquery. It may contain OuterRef() references to the outer

Exists

An explicit subquery. It may contain OuterRef() references to the outer

OrderBy

An expression that can be combined with other expressions.

Window

Some expressions with output_field=DecimalField() must be cast to

WindowFrame

Model the frame clause in window expressions. There are two types of frame

RowRange

Model the frame clause in window expressions. There are two types of frame

ValueRange

Model the frame clause in window expressions. There are two types of frame

class django.db.models.expressions.SQLiteNumericMixin[source]

Some expressions with output_field=DecimalField() must be cast to numeric to be properly filtered.

as_sqlite(compiler, connection, **extra_context)[source]
class django.db.models.expressions.Combinable[source]

Provide the ability to combine one or two objects with some connector. For example F(‘foo’) + F(‘bar’).

SUB = '-'[source]

DIV = '/'[source]

class django.db.models.expressions.BaseExpression(output_field=None)[source]

Base class for all query expressions.

empty_result_set_value = NotImplemented[source]
is_summary = False[source]
filterable = True[source]
window_compatible = False[source]
get_db_converters(connection)[source]
get_source_expressions()[source]
set_source_expressions(exprs)[source]
abstractmethod as_sql(compiler, connection)[source]

Responsible for returning a (sql, [params]) tuple to be included in the current query.

Different backends can provide their own implementation, by providing an as_{vendor} method and patching the Expression:

``` def override_as_sql(self, compiler, connection):

# custom logic return super().as_sql(compiler, connection)

setattr(Expression, ‘as_’ + connection.vendor, override_as_sql) ```

Parameters:

  • compiler (*) – the query compiler responsible for generating the query. Must have a compile method, returning a (sql, [params]) tuple. Calling compiler(value) will return a quoted value.

  • connection (*) – the database connection used for the current query.

Return: (sql, params)

Where sql is a string containing ordered sql parameters to be replaced with the elements of the list params.

contains_aggregate()[source]
contains_over_clause()[source]
contains_column_references()[source]
contains_subquery()[source]
resolve_expression(query=None, allow_joins=True, reuse=None, summarize=False, for_save=False)[source]

Provide the chance to do any preprocessing or validation before being added to the query.

Parameters:

  • query (*) – the backend query implementation

  • allow_joins (*) – boolean allowing or denying use of joins in this query

  • reuse (*) – a set of reusable joins for multijoins

  • summarize (*) – a terminal aggregate clause

  • for_save (*) – whether this expression about to be used in a save or update

Return: an Expression to be added to the query.

property conditional[source]
property field[source]
output_field()[source]

Return the output type of this expressions.

convert_value()[source]

Expressions provide their own converters because users have the option of manually specifying the output_field which may be a different type from the one the database returns.

get_lookup(lookup)[source]
get_transform(name)[source]
relabeled_clone(change_map)[source]

get_source_fields()[source]

Return the underlying field types used by this aggregate.

asc(**kwargs)[source]
desc(**kwargs)[source]
reverse_ordering()[source]
flatten()[source]

Recursively yield this expression and all subexpressions, in depth-first order.

select_format(compiler, sql, params)[source]

Custom format for select clauses. For example, EXISTS expressions need to be wrapped in CASE WHEN on Oracle.

class django.db.models.expressions.Expression(output_field=None)[source]

Bases: BaseExpression, Combinable

An expression that can be combined with other expressions.

identity()[source]
django.db.models.expressions.NoneType[source]
django.db.models.expressions.register_combinable_fields(lhs, connector, rhs, result)[source]
Register combinable types:

lhs <connector> rhs -> result

e.g.
register_combinable_fields(

IntegerField, Combinable.ADD, FloatField, FloatField

)

class django.db.models.expressions.CombinedExpression(lhs, connector, rhs, output_field=None)[source]

Bases: SQLiteNumericMixin, Expression

rhs[source]
get_source_expressions()[source]
set_source_expressions(exprs)[source]
as_sql(compiler, connection)[source]

Responsible for returning a (sql, [params]) tuple to be included in the current query.

Different backends can provide their own implementation, by providing an as_{vendor} method and patching the Expression:

``` def override_as_sql(self, compiler, connection):

# custom logic return super().as_sql(compiler, connection)

setattr(Expression, ‘as_’ + connection.vendor, override_as_sql) ```

Parameters:

  • compiler (*) – the query compiler responsible for generating the query. Must have a compile method, returning a (sql, [params]) tuple. Calling compiler(value) will return a quoted value.

  • connection (*) – the database connection used for the current query.

Return: (sql, params)

Where sql is a string containing ordered sql parameters to be replaced with the elements of the list params.

resolve_expression(query=None, allow_joins=True, reuse=None, summarize=False, for_save=False)[source]

Provide the chance to do any preprocessing or validation before being added to the query.

Parameters:

  • query (*) – the backend query implementation

  • allow_joins (*) – boolean allowing or denying use of joins in this query

  • reuse (*) – a set of reusable joins for multijoins

  • summarize (*) – a terminal aggregate clause

  • for_save (*) – whether this expression about to be used in a save or update

Return: an Expression to be added to the query.

class django.db.models.expressions.ResolvedOuterRef(name)[source]

Bases: F

An object that contains a reference to an outer query.

In this case, the reference to the outer query has been resolved because the inner query has been used as a subquery.

contains_aggregate = False[source]
contains_over_clause = False[source]

resolve_expression(query=None, allow_joins=True, reuse=None, summarize=False, for_save=False)[source]

Provide the chance to do any preprocessing or validation before being added to the query.

Parameters:

  • query (*) – the backend query implementation

  • allow_joins (*) – boolean allowing or denying use of joins in this query

  • reuse (*) – a set of reusable joins for multijoins

  • summarize (*) – a terminal aggregate clause

  • for_save (*) – whether this expression about to be used in a save or update

Return: an Expression to be added to the query.

as_sql(compiler, connection, function=None, template=None, arg_joiner=None, **extra_context)[source]

Responsible for returning a (sql, [params]) tuple to be included in the current query.

Different backends can provide their own implementation, by providing an as_{vendor} method and patching the Expression:

``` def override_as_sql(self, compiler, connection):

# custom logic return super().as_sql(compiler, connection)

setattr(Expression, ‘as_’ + connection.vendor, override_as_sql) ```

Parameters:

  • compiler (*) – the query compiler responsible for generating the query. Must have a compile method, returning a (sql, [params]) tuple. Calling compiler(value) will return a quoted value.

  • connection (*) – the database connection used for the current query.

Return: (sql, params)

Where sql is a string containing ordered sql parameters to be replaced with the elements of the list params.

class django.db.models.expressions.Ref(refs, source)[source]

Bases: Expression

Reference to column alias of the query. For example, Ref(‘sum_cost’) in qs.annotate(sum_cost=Sum(‘cost’)) query.

class django.db.models.expressions.ExpressionList(*expressions, **extra)[source]

Bases: Func

An expression containing multiple expressions. Can be used to provide a list of expressions as an argument to another expression, like a partition clause.

class django.db.models.expressions.ExpressionWrapper(expression, output_field)[source]

Bases: SQLiteNumericMixin, Expression

An expression that can wrap another expression so that it can provide extra context to the inner expression, such as the output_field.

Different backends can provide their own implementation, by providing an as_{vendor} method and patching the Expression:

``` def override_as_sql(self, compiler, connection):

resolve_expression(query=None, allow_joins=True, reuse=None, summarize=False, for_save=False)[source]

Provide the chance to do any preprocessing or validation before being added to the query.

Parameters:

  • query (*) – the backend query implementation

  • allow_joins (*) – boolean allowing or denying use of joins in this query

  • reuse (*) – a set of reusable joins for multijoins

  • summarize (*) – a terminal aggregate clause

  • for_save (*) – whether this expression about to be used in a save or update

Return: an Expression to be added to the query.

select_format(compiler, sql, params)[source]

Custom format for select clauses. For example, EXISTS expressions need to be wrapped in CASE WHEN on Oracle.

Provide the chance to do any preprocessing or validation before being added to the query.

as_sql(compiler, connection, template=None, **extra_context)[source]

Responsible for returning a (sql, [params]) tuple to be included in the current query.

Different backends can provide their own implementation, by providing an as_{vendor} method and patching the Expression:

``` def override_as_sql(self, compiler, connection):

# custom logic return super().as_sql(compiler, connection)

setattr(Expression, ‘as_’ + connection.vendor, override_as_sql) ```

Parameters:

  • compiler (*) – the query compiler responsible for generating the query. Must have a compile method, returning a (sql, [params]) tuple. Calling compiler(value) will return a quoted value.

  • connection (*) – the database connection used for the current query.

Return: (sql, params)

Where sql is a string containing ordered sql parameters to be replaced with the elements of the list params.

get_group_by_cols()[source]
class django.db.models.expressions.Case(*cases, default=None, output_field=None, **extra)[source]

Bases: SQLiteNumericMixin, Expression

An SQL searched CASE expression:

CASE
WHEN n > 0

THEN ‘positive’

WHEN n < 0

THEN ‘negative’

ELSE ‘zero’

END

template = 'CASE %(cases)s ELSE %(default)s END'[source]
case_joiner = ' '[source]
cases = [][source]
default[source]
extra[source]
get_source_expressions()[source]
set_source_expressions(exprs)[source]
resolve_expression(query=None, allow_joins=True, reuse=None, summarize=False, for_save=False)[source]

Provide the chance to do any preprocessing or validation before being added to the query.

Parameters:

  • query (*) – the backend query implementation

  • allow_joins (*) – boolean allowing or denying use of joins in this query

  • reuse (*) – a set of reusable joins for multijoins

  • summarize (*) – a terminal aggregate clause

  • for_save (*) – whether this expression about to be used in a save or update

Return: an Expression to be added to the query.

copy()[source]
as_sql(compiler, connection, template=None, case_joiner=None, **extra_context)[source]

Responsible for returning a (sql, [params]) tuple to be included in the current query.

Different backends can provide their own implementation, by providing an as_{vendor} method and patching the Expression:

``` def override_as_sql(self, compiler, connection):

# custom logic return super().as_sql(compiler, connection)

setattr(Expression, ‘as_’ + connection.vendor, override_as_sql) ```

Parameters:

  • compiler (*) – the query compiler responsible for generating the query. Must have a compile method, returning a (sql, [params]) tuple. Calling compiler(value) will return a quoted value.

  • connection (*) – the database connection used for the current query.

Return: (sql, params)

Where sql is a string containing ordered sql parameters to be replaced with the elements of the list params.

select_format(compiler, sql, params)[source]

Custom format for select clauses. For example, EXISTS expressions need to be wrapped in CASE WHEN on Oracle.

Responsible for returning a (sql, [params]) tuple to be included in the current query.

Different backends can provide their own implementation, by providing an as_{vendor} method and patching the Expression:

``` def override_as_sql(self, compiler, connection):

# custom logic return super().as_sql(compiler, connection)

setattr(Expression, ‘as_’ + connection.vendor, override_as_sql) ```

Parameters:

  • compiler (*) – the query compiler responsible for generating the query. Must have a compile method, returning a (sql, [params]) tuple. Calling compiler(value) will return a quoted value.

  • connection (*) – the database connection used for the current query.

class django.db.models.expressions.WindowFrame(start=None, end=None)[source]

Bases: Expression

Model the frame clause in window expressions. There are two types of frame clauses which are subclasses, however, all processing and validation (by no means intended to be complete) is done here. Thus, providing an end for a frame is optional (the default is UNBOUNDED FOLLOWING, which is the last row in the frame).

template = '%(frame_type)s BETWEEN %(start)s AND %(end)s'[source]
start[source]
end[source]
set_source_expressions(exprs)[source]

``` def override_as_sql(self, compiler, connection):

# custom logic return super().as_sql(compiler, connection)

Parameters:

  • connection (*) – the database connection used for the current query.
